channel.title: Help
channel.description:
So I develop software for a custom Linux distribution (Debian derivative).
Every release it's packed into a deb as you would expect.
But how can I develop the application on say my home computer and have it pulled for testing onto the test laptop I have?
Currently using Mercurial but I don't really want to have to commit every tiny change...

item.title: Help
item.dc:creator: @chri5 chri5
item.description:
@chri5 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:4, topic:405059”]I don’t understand why you have to test “every tiny change” on a second machine… why can’t you test it on the one you’re developing on?

(Also, commit early commit often is good embrace it!)[/quote]

Well the hardware is what will be shipping, so I have to make sure it’s all good. It uses special components (speech-dispatcher, orca etc) and emulating is balls.

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:5, topic:405059”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=502063.msg3674933#msg3674933 date=1311190657]
(Also, commit early commit often is good embrace it!)
[/quote]

Especially with git, since you can just roll them all into one big commit for your public repo! :)[/quote]
This sounds like a good idea. I really don’t want my “public” repo my manager sees to be full of 100 commits to fix a large bug… Every little thing has to be tested.

Read full topic

item.title: Help
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Mopman:

(Also, commit early commit often is good embrace it!)

Especially with git, since you can just roll them all into one big commit for your public repo!
